awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Conference: Promoting Cross-Disciplinary Dialogue Between Experts in Argumentation and Innovative Technologies
awd_abstract_narration:
Helping students develop the ability to construct high-quality arguments and to engage in productive argumentation with others is now widely seen as an essential goal of schooling that should be at the forefront of our efforts to develop an educated citizenry. From major policy documents, academic publications, and the popular press, we hear the call for teachers to prepare their students to make well-reasoned judgments about complex, controversial issues. Today, students are expected to actively engage in knowledge construction through inquiry and argumentation, by asking questions, defining problems, challenging the ideas of others, formulating their own positions, and supplying reasons and evidence for what otherwise would be unsupported opinions. These ambitious educational goals call for profound changes in the roles and responsibilities traditionally assigned to students and teachers. They require creative solutions, which include the use of innovative pedagogies and technologies.

This project will organize a workshop to support a dialogue among scholars in argumentation and technology, creating a shared space for researchers to discuss existing barriers and blind spots and engage in cross-disciplinary collaboration. During the two-day, online workshop, participants will present innovative research in their respective fields and form cross-disciplinary teams to discuss opportunities for joint projects and grant applications. In addition, participants will complete an open-ended online survey to address ideas, barriers, and opportunities for continued collaboration. They will also evaluate their experience during the workshop and suggest improvements for promoting dialogue between the fields of argumentation and technology. The workshop will bring together learning scientists specializing in research on argumentation and computer science experts developing innovative technologies, thus supporting frontier research in both fields. It will survey existing challenges in argumentation and technology, identify additional areas of concern, explore possible solutions, and create new opportunities for cross-disciplinary collaboration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of the two-day online workshop was to support collaboration among scholars in the fields of argumentation and technology. These fields of study are currently experiencing a period of rapid development, with many conceptual, pedagogical, and technological innovations designed in the past decade. Unfortunately, these innovations often stay within disciplinary boundaries, as they are typically disseminated through discipline-specific venues, such as academic conferences and publications. As a result, researchers are missing opportunities to learn about the latest developments in different fields, identify productive ways to capitalize on existing expertise in argumentation and emerging technologies, and conduct synergistic research that could advance knowledge in both fields.

 The workshop aimed to create a shared space for researchers to discuss existing barriers and blind spots, engage in cross-disciplinary collaboration, and explore possibilities for joint research projects. It brought together 24 scholars with expertise in argumentation, education, and computer science. Participants came from 16 universities, including universities in the U.S., Sweden, the Netherlands, Israel, Portugal, Chile, and Scotland. 54% of attendees were female.

 Prior to the workshop meeting, we asked participants to submit a two-page proposal. On Day 1 of the workshop, participants presented and discussed their research in argumentation and/or technology. These presentations introduced a variety of research initiatives, thus establishing a shared knowledge foundation for cross-disciplinary collaboration in small groups that took place on Day 2.

 Following the workshop, participants completed an anonymous, online survey. They were asked to rate their overall experience with the workshop and answer nine open-ended questions about workshop experiences, general barriers for productive cross-disciplinary collaboration, and strategies to promote synergistic research in the fields of argumentation and technology. We used Nvivo software to conduct thematic analysis of participants’ open-ended responses.

 The results show that participants had very positive reactions to the workshop. The mean rating of their overall experience was 4.6 on a 5-point scale (standard deviation=0.6). The written feedback from participants also indicates that the workshop was a valuable experience. Participants appreciated the opportunity to learn from each other, network, and collaborate.

 The workshop also exposed the complexity of facilitating cross-disciplinary research. It highlighted issues with recruitment, difficulties with understanding the other discipline, and challenges with identifying overlapping interests.

 Reflecting on workshop experiences and feedback received from participants, we have the following recommendations for future workshop organizers:

  1. Ensure balanced representation from both fields through targeted recruitment strategies.
  2. Facilitate smoother team formation and increase commitment to attending the event through pre-workshop communication and coordination.
  3. Allocate time for in-depth discussions and collaboration, possibly extending the duration of the workshop.
  4. Use multiple formats for organizing collaboration and forming groups. This includes open-ended discussions as well as structured sessions, with specific pre-determined topics, goals, and tasks. It also includes alternating among various group formation strategies, such as self-selected, topic-based, and random assignment.
  5. Consider devoting an entire workshop to a narrow topic in cross-disciplinary work, such as the use of readily available technology or automated assessment of argument writing.
  6. Establish a post-workshop platform for participants to continue discussions and collaborations.
  7. As part of the workshop, provide funding opportunities for small, exploratory, ‘start-up’ projects that encourage scholars to form cross-disciplinary teams, pilot new ideas, and build capacity for larger collaborative endeavors.

 To conclude, we were encouraged to see a lot of creativity, excitement, and curiosity about cross-disciplinary work in argumentation and technology from both fields of study. Scholars presented and discussed innovative projects and ideas that can potentially lead to endless possibilities for meaningful and impactful collaboration. At the same time, it became clear that the two communities are largely confined within their disciplinary boundaries. They have profoundly different approaches to conducting research, with distinct priorities, problems, analytic methods, and potential solutions. There are also gaps in understanding, including stereotypes and misconceptions about the other discipline, as scholars have limited opportunities to engage with each other’s work. Addressing these challenges will require sustained and ongoing effort needed to identify and promote various mechanisms, platforms, and activities that support cross-disciplinary work in argumentation and technology.
